title: Navigating the Marketplace of Indicators
descriptions:
Here is a 296-word abstract for the grant proposal:

Title: Navigating the Marketplace of Indicators

The proliferation of country performance indicators (CPIs) has created a paradoxical situation where individual indicators simplify complex issues, but collectively, they complicate decision-making in various policy fields. This project, "Navigating the Marketplace of Indicators," addresses the research gap in navigating policy fields with multiple CPIs. Inspired by the concept of a "marketplace of ideas," this study will investigate how users and producers of CPIs adapt over time in response to the abundance of indicators.

Focusing on education, global governance, climate policy, and pandemic preparedness, this systemic and longitudinal analysis will explore how users learn from criticism of CPIs and make decisions with diverse indicators. On the producer side, the project will examine the dynamics of competition within crowded policy fields. By shedding light on the complex interactions between CPI users and producers, this research aims to shift the problem focus in CPI research, moving from individual indicator development to a more systematic understanding of the CPI landscape.

Ultimately, this project seeks to provide insights into how to navigate the abundance of CPIs, enabling more effective decision-making and policy implementation in various fields. By advancing our understanding of the CPI marketplace, this research has the potential to inform evidence-based policy decisions, promoting better outcomes in education, global governance, climate policy, and pandemic preparedness.

**Title:** Navigating the Marketplace of Indicators

The abundance of country performance indicators (CPIs) has created a paradox: while individual indicators simplify complex issues, their collective presence complicates decision-making. The "marketplace of indicators" has become overcrowded, with multiple CPIs competing for attention in various policy fields, including education, global governance, climate policy, and pandemic preparedness. This project aims to investigate how CPI users and producers adapt to this complexity over time.

Despite the proliferation of CPIs, there is a significant research gap in understanding how to navigate these indicators effectively. This study addresses this gap by adopting a systemic, longitudinal approach inspired by the concept of a "marketplace of ideas." Our research will focus on both CPI users, examining how they learn from criticism and make decisions with diverse indicators, and CPI producers, analyzing the competitive dynamics within crowded policy fields.

By exploring the complex interactions between CPI users and producers, this project seeks to advance our understanding of the CPI landscape and identify opportunities for improvement. The study's findings will contribute to a systematic problem shift in CPI research, enabling more effective use of indicators in policy decision-making. Ultimately, this project will provide valuable insights for policymakers, researchers, and practitioners seeking to navigate the marketplace of indicators and make informed decisions in an increasingly complex global environment.
